page.title: 08LOCAL HISTORY
page.content:
The village of Jemimaville was originally built about 1822 as estate houses for the Poyntzfield estate and called Jemimaville after Jemima Poyntz, the laird's wife. Then it was a thriving community with its own doctor, dancing master, various tradesmen and a hotel. It even had a hand loom weaving industry for a time. There was a village hall and two churches. Then the trade died away and the estate dwindelled. Many of the old buildings decayed. Now one church is just a ruin on the shore. The other is now a garage and petrol station. Some of the buildings were turned into private houses, one of which , the old store and warehouse, belonged to Jane Duncan, the Scottish authoress.
continued on page 9
